title: Wednesday, 9th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hi, hello, hey, good morning.

BE

So Paul's still out at lunch.

BE

I quit early, at 3am, me and Iz having somehow made it to Cafe Italia.

11:04 am
BE

Anyway, it might be a bit rough today. Because that's the prevailing state of the desk.

BE

And, yeah, only one possibility for the portrait today.

BE

11:05 am
BE

Dr Craig Steven Wright of Wagga Wagga.

BE

Who might have done a thing.

BE

Or not. Possibly.

11:05 am
BE

Wired puts it thusly ...

BE

BITCOIN'S CREATOR SATOSHI NAKAMOTO IS PROBABLY THIS UNKNOWN AUSTRALIAN GENIUS

BE

http://www.wired.c...australian-genius/

11:06 am
BE

And coincidentally, he's just had his house and offices raided by Aussie tax authorities.

BE

http://www.theguar...chnology_b-gdntech

BE

Check this out for a story parachute.

11:07 am
BE

Despite that overwhelming collection of clues, none of it fully proves that Wright is Nakamoto. All of it could be an elaborate hoax—perhaps orchestrated by Wright himself. The unverified leaked documents could be faked in whole or in part. And most inexplicably of all, comparisons of different archived versions of the three smoking gun posts from Wright’s blog show that he did edit all three—to insert evidence of his bitcoin history. The PGP key associated with Nakamoto’s email address and references to an upcoming “cryptocurrency paper” and “triple entry accounting” were added sometime after 2013. Even the post noting bitcoin’s beta launch is questionable. While it was ostensibly posted in January 2009, it later seems to have been deleted and then undeleted—or possibly even written for the first time—sometime between October 2013 and June of 2014.

BE

So while the circumstantial evidence is convincing, there's also circumstantial evidence that he invented the circumstantial evidence.

BE

thumbs up

11:07 am
BE

Oh, and the only person capable of corroborating the story is dead.

BE

thumbs up

BE

Though only a weirdo would fake this stuff, surely.

11:08 am
BE

Unrelatedly, here's Dr Wright's bio.

BE

BE

thumbs up

11:08 am
BE

But what would a rather peculiar man who owns a Bitcoin bank have to gain by being publicly identified as the creator of Bitcoin at the same time as that bank collapsed?

BE

It sure is a mystery.

BE

thumbs up

11:09 am
undefined
BE

So, yeah, Anglo.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 323.65, down 45.35 (-12.29%), High: 365.15, Low: 322.65, Volume: 26.44m
11:10 am
BE

Still not ex FTSE, according to my data. Still slightly more than £4bn, which puts it a few places above relegation territory.

BE

What we can say is that it's down 75% year to date.

BE

(@Roddy: I cannot be drawn on that.)

11:11 am
BE

Bloody hell, is autopricing down? Hold on ......

Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 625.00, down 43.5 (-6.51%), High: 656.00, Low: 612.50, Volume: 1.29m
BE

Nope, just looks like Anglo can't autoprice any more.

11:11 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 292.45, down 31.2 (-9.64%), High: 334.20, Low: 277.60, Volume: 12.87m
BE

There we go. System was in denial earlier. Much like Cutifani.

BE

Whose presentation yesterday was underwhelming.

11:13 am
BE

So, yeah, they're closing a load of stuff and classing other stuff as non core. Including stuff that they bought for more than the entire company's current market cap.

BE

It's still not a buy though, because the likelihood of a rights issue is the elephant in the room.

BE

Here's RBC .....

11:14 am
BE

The steps look right, but music is wrong:

BE

Anglo has detailed an even
more drastic rehabilitation strategy aimed at bringing the balance sheet
back to health. These steps include the decision to pass the dividend, cut
capex and opex and boost disposals. The number of assets is to fall from
55 in 2014 to ~20 in the medium-term, and people employed reduced
from 162k in 2013 to a target of ~50k. But with net debt of $13-$13.5bn
and market cap of ~$6.5bn, focus remains on the debt top-heavy balance
sheet. This is likely to continue to weigh on the investment rating, we
think, with the market focusing on whether Anglo is the next company to
need additional equity. Essentially we think the challenge in getting decent
prices for assets in a tough resource market will continue to predispose
investors to the view that Anglo needs equity. At current market prices,
we believe equity issuance would be a tough call. Should equity indeed be
needed the share price would come under more pressure, in our view.

BE

The pith of the strategy: Anglo will comprise three visions: De Beers,
Industrial Metals (base and PGMs) and Bulks (coal and iron ore). Within
these divisions the assets regarded as core include Diamonds, PGMs
and Copper. The rest have slipped down the ranking because of their
positions and potential positions on cost curves given Anglo's new lower
(undisclosed) long-term price assumptions. Disposals have also been
expanded by $2bn to $4bn, capex and opex are cut and the dividend will
be passed until end-2016, at the earliest.

11:15 am
BE

Changing numbers: We adjust our model to reflect updated guidance.
Overall, we see an uplift to our EPS forecasts which reflects lower D&A
charges following impairments at AngloPlat, coupled with efforts to cut
costs. Our NAV reduces to £9.36/sh which reflects production volume cuts,
particularly in iron ore.

BE

Investment summary: For more than two years Anglo has been trying
to pull operations into more economic shape and reduce debt. Falling
commodity prices made the task ever more challenging. The new strategy
is, in essence, more of the same but tailored for tougher times. The
strategy makes sense, but the time to complete it is likely to be prolonged.
This will likely weigh on the share price. We lower our Price Target to
£3.00. The risk to our Sector Perform rating remains the balance sheet and
potential need for equity.

BE

As requested, here's RBC's NAV.

11:15 am
BE

BE

And clearly, there's some flex in all those numbers.

BE

The SocGen note referred to on the right is , I think, from the credit team.

11:17 am
BE

Possible downgrade to non-IG priced in; capital increase/bolder divestments cannot be
ruled out: To judge by the market response to the announced portfolio restructuring,
dividend suspension, capex cuts and planned divestments (shares down 12%, CDS 70bp
wider, and cash bonds between 60-80bp wider), Anglo American’s (Baa2 neg/BBB- stable)
investor day failed to dissipate balance sheet fears. Even if we assume the group does not
deliver on the targeted asset sales by end 2017 and that current commodity prices persist
into 2016 and 2017 (not SG base case), we estimate the group’s credit metrics would be
commensurate with mid-to-high BB ratings (adj. FFO/net debt between 15-20%). We also
believe management would consider a capital increase or bolder divestments (e.g. Minas
Rio) if commodity prices were to fall further. Our Sell 5yr CDS call reflects SG’s moderately
bullish view on base metals/iron ore prices vs spot (See Commodities Review) and cheap
valuations (815/855) given the limited implications from a potential downgrade to the BB
category, in our view. AALLN cash bonds (Hold €) are likely to be more volatile as forced
sellers could emerge. We nonetheless raise our recommendation to Buy from Hold on
AALLN Nov 2017 € bonds (5.3% ytm), which are comfortably covered by its strong liquidity
position and could be subject to company buybacks in our view (c.93 cash price).

BE

We note that S&P’s BBB- rating on AALLN assumes negative discretionary cash flows in
2015/2016, no change in the dividend policy, and no new divestments on top of the $2bn
already achieved. Hence we believe the main catalyst for a downgrade would have to be a
material downward revision to S&P’s commodity price assumptions for 2016/2017.
AALLN’s liquidity profile remains strong at $15bn vs bond maturities of $1.6bn and $2.6bn
in FY16/FY17 respectively. The group has no financial covenants/MAC clause in its core
$5bn RCF at the parent level (undrawn, maturing in April 2020). Management flagged that
covenant headroom at Sishen (Kumba’s subsidiary) will become tight in FY16. We would
expect the group to seek a waiver from the banks or worse case to repay the facilities with
limited impact on group liquidity given Sishen’s small net debt position ($440m).
Investor day unveils radical portfolio restructuring and new cash savings/raising
initiatives: The group announced medium-term plans to reduce scale by eliminating assets
(c.20 vs 55 in FY14, workforce to fall by 70%) that are not in or moving to the first quartile
of the cost curve and that can generate positive free cash flow through the cycle. The
group will be re-organised in three divisions: De Beers, Industrial Metals (platinum, base
metals) and Bulk Commodities (coal, iron ore). In addition, management announced further
capex cuts of $1bn by end 2016, an increased asset disposal target of $4bn (with $2bn left
to do in FY16/FY17) and a dividend suspension for H215 and FY16 ($1.1bn cash saving
pa). The group’s dividend policy will change to a target payout ratio when the dividend
resumes. Management reiterated its FY15 net debt guidance of $13-13.5bn and now
targets net debt below $10bn in the medium term (previous guidance was $10-12bn).

BE

Oh, actually, there's one from the equities team too .....

11:18 am
BE

 Investors are clearly not impressed by Anglo American’s (AA) management initiatives with
the stock down c. 8% yesterday. The incremental cash savings to come in the form of
savings/productivity gains fell below market expectations with only $1.0bn additional EBITDA
pledged for FY 17 (on top of a revised down target of $1.1bn in FY16), combined with a
$1.1bn cut in dividends (probably already factored in by the market). Other initiatives are
clearly conceptual at this stage, i.e., more asset sales, closure of assets that lack a clear
roadmap to positive FCF, etc..
 On spot price, AA's numbers look very weak. Spot EBITDA is at $3.5bn inc. $2.0bn for core
assets. This, alongside guidance of negative FCF next year and only breakeven in FY17,
makes absolute net debt at $13-$13.5bn (end FY 15 target) a real concern. That’s 3.9x Net
debt to EBITDA. Management itself reckons that AA’s net debt target should be below $10bn.
 What is the end game for Anglo? We think AA should not wait until February 2016 to take
further initiatives. Given that its capex projections are already at or close to maintenance
levels ($2.5bn in FY 17) and that there are legitimate question marks regarding the execution
of AA’s “Radical change” strategy, we think AA needs to come up with a quicker source of
cash, i.e., rapidly materialise asset disposals both on its “asset for sale list” (Niobium,
Phosphate, etc) and not on the list (Minas Rio?) and/or issue shares.

BE

 Investor sentiment is unlikely to reverse anytime soon and, barring a sector rally, at this
stage there is likely more downside risk than upside risk to the share. If an equity issuance is
the ultimate choice, waiting any longer would mean more dilution. Management also needs to
be mindful that at current market capitalisation ($6.2bn), AA is likely to be on the radar of
companies looking for good assets overshadowed by distressed balance sheets.
 We plan to update our models shortly in light of all the new news. Our valuation methodology
is a blended NPV (using a WACC of 8.6%) and 6.0x EV/EBITDA. We obtain our TP by using a
weighted average of a base-case scenario (70% -4.9x 17e EV/EBITDA, and a “Spot-10%”
scenario (30%). Risks to TP: downside –steel production and manganese prices failing to
recover as we model; technical challenges and hazards; project cost overruns; deteriorating ore
grades; geopolitics; upside – rapid materialisation of cash; asset base stabilisation.

BE

Grim.

11:19 am

11:23 am
BE

On Rio, its aluminium investor day yesterday seems to have been quite positive.

BE

Relatively speaking. Figures edging up on the back of it.

BE

Single line from Barclays ......

11:24 am
BE

We update our Rio Tinto model for recent developments. These are focused on the
aluminium division, in particular approval of the Amrun bauxite project, new 2016
production guidance, updated aluminium maintenance capex guidance, reduced
smelting unit costs in 2016 and new group-level capex guidance for 2015 and 2016.
These changes leave us upgrading EBITDA by 1% and 3% in 2015-16E, respectively,
and EPS by 1% and 6%, respectively. Lower net debt and higher EBITDA leave the
balance sheet better positioned too. On spot we still see the dividend as uncovered
but believe the company has the means to bridge the gap from asset disposals, cost
reductions (particularly in iron ore) and further flexibility over capex.

BE

Rather more from Canaccord.

BE

Aluminium and capital expenditure
Aluminium, is Rio Tinto's second largest business area, and was the theme for this year's
Investor Day, together with commentary on group capital expenditure.
The aluminium market
Rio Tinto expects the aluminium market to gradually move back to balance as excess
inventories erode, though progress has been negatively impacted by rapid Chinese
capacity growth. Prices are now cutting deep into the cost curve but a rapid recovery is
not anticipated; it may take five years for inventories to return to normal levels. Rio sees
long-term average global demand growth of 3.5-4%, driven primarily by the transport
sector. Aluminium per passenger vehicle in North America is expected to increase
60% by 2030. Meanwhile, China's aluminium sector is facing increasing headwinds;
declining domestic bauxite quality, and growing transport challenges from bauxite mines
to alumina refineries. Chinese imported bauxite demand could grow by 8% p.a..
Cost savings
Since 2013, the aluminium segment has recorded cumulative cash cost reductions of
US$1.1bn from raw material savings (US$456M), fixed production costs (US$437M) and
functional support costs (US$211M) from lower headcount and services restructuring,
with further benefits from weaker exchange rates and oil. This has resulted in an
upstream EBITDA margin that exceeds key competitors.

11:25 am
BE

The Amrun bauxite mine development
Rio Tinto approved this US$1.9bn project in November, with capex primarily expected in
2017/18. Amrun should allow Rio to enhance its third party sales, particularly to China,
which is expected to import 50Mt of bauxite this year. Amrun will produce 22.8Mtpa of
bauxite, replacing East Weipa and adding c.10Mtpa to exports.The project has a 40-
year mine life, first quartile costs and project returns of over 20%. First shipments are
expected in H1 2019, and the mine has expansion options to 50Mtpa.
Group capital expenditure cut further
Rio Tinto has confirmed that it now expects 2015 groupwide capital expenditure to be
c.US$5.0bn (previously c.US$5.5bn) while in 2016 a similar figure, c.US$5bn, is now
forecast, down from previous forecasts of less than US$6bn. There was no comment
on 2017 capex, which was forecast at US$7.0bn with the 2015 interims. Note that the
spend at Amrun is expected to be around US$700M in 2017.
Our view
Rio Tinto remains our preferred diversified mining investment, and is the only company
that has the potential to actually increase its full-year 2015 dividend. With the iron ore
price hitting new lows, and abundant negative sentiment, further share price downside
is a possibility in the short-term. While we will review our commodity and exchange rate
assumptions in January, reflecting recent price weakness, we remain confident of the
longer term potential for the company, and maintain our BUY rating.

undefined
BE

And so to profit warnings.

11:26 am
Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 306.70, down 49.4 (-13.87%), High: 342.00, Low: 295.10, Volume: 1.61m
BE

People aren't taking the bus due to Isis.

BE

That's the gist of it.

11:27 am
BE

Consensus comes down 6%

BE

More importantly, perhaps, the possibility of a special div disappears.

BE

Morgan Stanley can summarise it, to save my typing.

11:28 am
BE

Stagecoach reports 1H 2016 EPS of 17.0p, which compares to MSe of 17.3p,
and a group EBITA of £144.6m vs. MSe £142m, driven by solid performance in
UK Rail. On outlook, SGC are “cautious”, due to 1) softer regional UK Bus rev
growth and 2) lower rail/coach growth in UK/Europe since mid-November,
and as a result, expects a “modest revision to FY adjusted EPS”, of around -5%.
Our FY EPS estimate stands at 29.5p, in-line with consensus at 29.5p. Overall,
1H numbers are solid, but the focus today will be on the weaker outlook and
EPS revisions.

BE

Outlook: SGC has seen a lower rate of revenue growth across both UK Rail
and megabus Europe since mid-November, as a result of the terrorist attacks
in Paris, which has discouraged travel to major cities (though this is expected
to recover in 2H). In addition, SGC reports softer than expected revenue across
parts of the regional UK Bus business (including flooding from recent storms
and congestion in Manchester). As a result of the above, SGC expect a
reduction in '16 EBITA for Regional Bus of c. £13m (MSe £135m) and another
£5m for '17 (MSe £142m). Overall as a result, SGC expects consensus EPS to
come down c. 5% in '16 (from 29.5p to around 28-28.5p) and 5% in '17 (from
c. 30p to c. 29p).

BE

Regarding Rail, SGC has announced its decision to withdraw from its bid with
Abellio for the East Anglia franchise, as it was unable to agree on certain terms
of the bid with Abellio. Separately, the DfT has today awarded the TPE
franchise to FirstGroup (SGC was shortlisted).
Balance sheet: As expected, net debt increased over the 1H, to £458m (or c.
1.2x net debt/EBITDA) from £381m at FY2015 (1.2x net debt/EBITDA) due to
increased bus investment, higher interest and premium costs from early bond
redemption, and the reversal of some favourable UK Rail working capital
timing differences last year, partly offset by continued strong cash generation.

11:29 am
BE

And Deutsche.

BE

There can be no hiding our disappointment at several aspects of the first half
results. Trading has been impacted by a multitude of factors - some new, some
one-off and some recurring. A special dividend looks remote until possibly
FY17 at the earliest. We have cut our earnings estimates for FY16 by 6%, for
FY17 by 9%, and our target price by 15% to 390p. Despite this, and after
reflecting on the recommendation and make-up of our earnings cuts, we still
believe Stagecoach is a mid-term high return business that is under-levered
and not priced aggressively. Today may be grim, but we maintain buy.

BE

The rub is that our operating profit estimates for UK Bus are cut materially
(FY16 from £135m to £122m; FY17 from £139m to £134m), similarly for UK
Rail in FY17 (FY16 from £66m to £63m; FY17 from £60m to £45m) but London
Bus, North America and Joint Ventures are broadly unchanged. Overall we are
cutting our Group EBITA forecast by 6%, and also our EPS by 6% with the
financial gearing offset by marginal tax rate improvement to 19%.
Clearly investors are likely to focus on the £13m cut to FY16 UK bus operating
profit. On page three we detail exactly how this number is built up. The
conclusion however is that nine million is arguably one-off in nature, a
combination of weak intercity bookings following the Paris attacks and
extremely bad roadworks. The last three to four million however is an out and
out slowing of underlying revenue growth. Unfortunately this move has no
obvious explanation and is a continuation of regional macro and general
passenger weakness. It is this part of the downgrade that carries most weight,
and is potentially recurring. As such, we think it prudent to carry forward a
£5m cut to our FY17 UK bus forecasts as well.
The earnings cut in UK rail, as well as the effective termination of the joint bid
with Abellio for East Anglia, are also detailed on page three.

11:03 am
BE

Did we mention it was AV's Christmas lunch yesterday?

BE

No response from the sector, which some might see as slightly surprising ......

BE

11:35 am
BE

undefined
BE

Ophir? Certainly.

11:35 am
Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 89.60, up 2.6 (+2.99%), High: 91.60, Low: 88.40, Volume: 1.78m
BE

So, further progress with Fortuna. Gas sold forward and, more importantly perhaps, capex guidance down again.

BE

Credit Suisse summarises .........

11:37 am
BE

■ Lower capex to first gas: Ophir announced capex to first gas for Fortuna
FLNG is now expected to be 25% lower, at a gross cost of $600m ($480m
net) from $800m previously. The potential for lower capex was well flagged
at the capital markets day in November, but is still a positive development.
The announcement came earlier than expected given the upstream FEED
process is only 50% complete, and is scheduled to finish around end-1Q16.
■ HoAs signed with six counterparties: Heads of Agreements (HOAs) for
LNG offtake have been signed with six counterparties, more than covering
Fortuna's expected production of 2.2mtpa. The HoAs come in a variety of
different pricing structures, with links to European hub prices, oil indexation
or a combination of both. Several of the HoAs also contain profit sharing
clauses in the event an LNG cargo is diverted to premium markets.
■ Potential for gas pre-payments: Financing remains one of the key hurdles
for Ophir to take FID on Fortuna FLNG, and it alluded at the CMD that there
were options beyond a traditional farm-down. Some of the HoAs contain gas
pre-payment clauses, which could cover 30-50% of Ophir's net costs to first
gas. However, these contracts likely come with concessions in other areas
such as a less attractive pricing formula. The level of financing on offer also
depends on the amount of off-take secured, hence the 30-50% range.

BE

■ Catalysts: Ophir intends to narrow down the current short list of six buyers to
one or two in 1Q16, with final contracts to be signed at FID around mid-2016.
■ Valuation: We increase our TP to 110p/sh (from 100p/sh) to reflect lower
expected capex to first gas for Fortuna FLNG, which is a round up to our
risked NAV of 107p/sh.

BE

And Davy .............

11:38 am
BE

Further to an announcement on November 11 th , Ophir has
confirmed that it has signed heads of agreement with six
counterparties for LNG offtake from the Fortuna gas
development project. Importantly, an element of the HOAs
includes the offer to pre-pay for LNG volumes in substantial
quantities over the early years of the contract. Management
also advises of a 25% reduction in capex to first gas. Reduced
investment before the start of operating cash-flow should
make the project more attractive to potential equity partners.

BE

LNG buyers offer a potential source of funding
Having finalised commercial terms with a group of counterparties last month, Ophir has
confirmed (December 9 th ) that it has now signed heads of agreement (HOA) with the
group. The six counterparties are described as established LNG buyers in the Asian and
European markets. There will now follow a further shortlisting process to select one or
two of these LNG buyers with whom to sign full sales and purchase agreements (SPAs) in
Q1 2016. This timing is in line with the planned project final investment decision (FID) in
mid-2016.
Importantly, the HOA includes the offer to pre-pay for LNG volumes in substantial
quantities over the early years of the contract. The funds received from pre-payments
could potentially cover 30-50% of Ophir’s total net cost to first gas.
Ideally, Ophir would like to divest up to 40% of its 80% equity in the Fortuna project in
return for a cost carry to first gas. We felt this was a difficult endeavour given the
backdrop (collapsed LNG prices and market dynamics in flux). The option of pre-payment
could provide an attractive optional or secondary source of funding depending on the
terms and improves Ophir’s bargaining position when pursing other sources of finance. .
Reduced up-front capital at risk helpful for finding equity partners
Competitive cost and engineering studies for the Fortuna project are now 50% complete
and management advises that initial results conclude a 25% reduction in capex to first
gas. This reduction implies that Ophir’s net share of capex is now estimated to be
$480m, down from a $640m estimate previously. It is not clear if the reduction in capex
to first oil is merely a postponement of capex until production is up and running or a
reduction in the overall capex budget which was previously estimated at $3bn. The
announcement does refer to cost deflation and design standardisation rather than
project re-phasing as reasons for capex reductions. In any case, reduced investment
before the start of operating cash-flow should make the project a more attractive or
palatable proposition for potential equity partners.

BE

Was in at Panmure yesterday, incidentally, where the oil analyst Colin Smith was among those presenting.

11:39 am
BE

Theory was along the lines of the oil market going from surplus to deficit by mid 2016,

BE

So, once Opec stops its siege and there's a floor under Brent, the sector basically doubles.

BE

However, you still shouldn't buy now.

11:41 am
BE

I'm not really doing his argument justice here. Will share his year-start note whenever it arrives.

undefined
BE

(@Via Con: why not?)

11:42 am
BE

So Entertainment One says trading's in line with expectations ......

BE

............... which was absolutely nothing to do with its recent annihilation.

BE

The annihilation was on a breathtakingly expensive debt refinancing shortly after a rights issue, which drew attention to the business's strange inability to generate actual cash.

11:43 am
BE

Still, it's trading in line with expectations, so that's nice.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 158.00, up 17.1 (+12.14%), High: 158.30, Low: 150.40, Volume: 2.07m
BE

Peel Hunt's closed its short.

11:44 am
BE

Having gone into the money rather quicker than anyone could've expected.

BE

In response to the share price fall ETO has this morning
reiterated the detail of the refinancing. The flexibility of the
covenant-light loan is being paid for by sharply higher interest
cost. We leave our target price unchanged but expect the share
price to rise after the aggressive falls that have happened as the
market digested another EPS reduction so soon after the interims
and the dilutive rights issue.

BE

For a fuller defence, we can turn to RBC

11:45 am
BE

Which said this overnight, pre statement.

BE

• A content rerating story gone wrong. In June 2015, we initiated
coverage of ETO with an Outperform rating. Considering the dramatic
decline in the shares since then (including -35% this week) our call
clearly did not play out as we had hoped. While last week's debt
refinancing cannot by itself explain this week's pullback, we believe it
has compounded pre-existing negative sentiment reflecting (i) further
EPS reduction after a number of downward revisions recently (weaker
Film performance, dilutive rights issue); and (ii) speculation that
uses of proceeds could include further acquisitions, at a time when
investor appetite is low and ETO's valuation is depressed. While we
remain bullish on the growth opportunities for content production &
distribution in an evolving TV ecosystem, it will likely take time to restore
investor confidence in the story, preferably through organic execution.

• Trimming EPS forecast on recent refinancing. On Friday, eOne
announced the issuance of £285MM in 6.875% Senior Secured Notes
due December 2022. Net proceeds will be used to repay existing credit
facilities (January 2018 expiry) and for general corporate purposes.
eOne also anticipates replacing its existing credit facilities with a new
five year £100MM revolver maturing December 2020. The refinancing
results in higher interest expense versus our prior estimates - roughly
£21MM/year including amortization of financing costs. Our adjusted
f.d. EPS estimate (eOne's definition) decreases ~10% in F2017E.
Management indicated that higher interest costs reflect the covenant-
light and flexible nature of the facility.

on top of our EV/EBITDA and DCF valuations in order to better capture
the dilution associated with the refinancing and recent rights offering.

value greater than US$1.2B, or greater than £800MM versus a current adjusted EV of ~£840MM (implying little value in the company's underlying business).

Ashtead’s 2Q16 results are robust. Revenues were 1.5% below company provided consensus, EBITDA 0.6% below consensus, but PBTA was 3% ahead and EPS 7% ahead. Gross capex in 2Q16 was £347m, and gross capex for FY16 is now expected to be c. £1.1bn, compared to previous guidance of around £1bn. Ashtead expects FY16 results to be ahead of expectations. Within Sunbelt same store growth was 13% (compared to 13% in 1Q, and 17% in FY15), and bolt ons added 8%. Yield for Sunbelt was flat, compared to +0% in 1Q16. In A-Plant rental revenue was up 8%, with fleet on rent up 7%, compared to 10% in 1Q, and yield was up 1% after 0% in 1Q16.

BE

We are Overweight on Ashtead as we believe Ashtead will continue to
benefit from the cyclical tailwinds of the US non-residential construction market, gains in market share, and the structural trend towards renting. Ashtead is on a CY 2016 EV/EBITDA of 5.4x, and PER of 12.0x. Estimates: we currently forecast a FY16 (ended April 2016) profit before tax of £603m, in line with Bloomberg consensus of £605m.

12:00 pm
BE

John Wiley the latest. Yesterday the stock fell 10% in the US following Q2 sales report of $433m, well below $460m expected. Biggest fall was in Books, particularly in education with print textbooks sales falling 22% and custom materials falling 25%. A sharp decline in books was impacted by lower enrolments, channel inventory consumption, fewer adoptions and increased penetration by rental. There is a change in behaviour by students moving away from traditional print textbooks moving to used textbooks, rental model and digital sales. Retailers are burning books inventory as demand slackens and marketplace disruption continues. Wiley suggest the inventory correction is across the channel which would have clear negative implications for Pearson.

And don’t forget the significance of the timing of Wiley’s poor results. With a Q2 ending in October this captures much of the key back-to-school season in the US which is clearly weaker than expectations. Wiley’s EBIT fell

20% YoY in Q2. Currently Street forecasts (mean estimates from Capital IQ) Pearson will achieve £740m of EBIT (including 11 month contribution from FT) for 2015 and £692m for FY16. Essentially flat YoY for FY16 for the Education business. It is likely only flat it we get the mother of warnings for H2 2015 (likely).

We now count evidence in the supply chain and industry from Wiley, Graham, Houghton, Apollo, UTI, Capella, Devry, American Public, Coronthian, Strayer, Cengagde, Emmanuel, Career Education and Grand Canyon in recent weeks/months during the critical back-to-school season. ALL ARE NEGATIVE.

Whether you look to the K-12 segment, or to Technical ed, Higher Education, China, behavioural changes, structural risks, college budgets, regulation change the headwinds are huge. And we expect Pearson will have a huge moment within the next three months – as in a HUGE WARNING.

BE

Deutsche ditto. Think this came out yesterday.

BE

We think Pearson’s problems are structural, with cyclical pressures
exacerbating them. The challenges are most acute in US College (approx. 35%
profits) and where a reduction in margin to the level of the school business
would negatively impact profits by 15%. Over time, we think the education
market is becoming more competitive, as the old print-based oligopolies are
challenged by free content and new entrants.

12:02 pm
BE

We examine the returns issue and find more risk
Pearson’s October trading statement blamed higher returns of unsold college
books. In this note, we examine the issue of returns and find risk of further
downside. Our new estimates are 7% below consensus.
Risks include acquisitions, return of cash
Risks to our bear case include potential acquisitions, which, although
uncertain, could be mid-single digit accretive to EPS. Other risks include a rise
in college enrollments, which could be driven by an increase in US
unemployment, or “free college” schemes.
Valuation: we cut TP, maintain SELL
Pearson is trading on 13x PE 2016E and 15x P/FCF, which could appear low
compared to peers, but Pearson is experiencing organic revenue decline and
has not grown more than 1% since 2010. We cut our TP to 770p from 950p.
Our TP is based on an average of PE and EV/EBITDA versus peers and DCF
(8.5% WACC, terminal growth 1.1%, a weighted average of TG rates at North
America, Core and Growth segments).

It’s clear that today’s results are disappointing. Our forecast of a special
dividend in FY16 has proven too early - we have now moved it back to FY17.
Earnings cuts for this year and next are material (c6%-10%) and more
importantly impacting the crown jewel that is regional bus. The inability to
reach a joint bid with Abellio is obviously disappointing given that the joint
venture would have been well placed to win.
But after picking apart the downgrade we find that although some parts are
clearly concerning, and potentially recurring, at least half ought to be one-off in
nature. Similarly whereas the delay of a capital return is clearly a blow to our
thesis, it doesn’t change the fact that Stagecoach is still underlevered – the
cash has not disappeared. Taking a step back, even post our earnings revisions
and pre-market open Stagecoach trades at 12.2x April-17 which isn’t a price
for perfection. Therefore whilst we are reducing our target price by 15% to
390p we maintain buy and see medium term value. Our investment case,
valuation, forecast changes and risks are shown on pages three to five. We
value SGC using a FY17 EV/EBITA multiple of 12.0x, a small premium to the
five year average. The key risk to our view is a continued deterioration in
regional bus volumes
